messages.content:
New Vulnerability in GitHub Copilot, Cursor: Hackers Can Weaponize Code Agents
 
New Vulnerability in GitHub Copilot, Cursor: Hackers Can Weaponize Code Agents
pillar.security ‚Ä¢ 165 points ‚Ä¢ pseudolus ‚Ä¢ 15 hours ago
100 comments
DougBTX ‚Ä¢ 9 hours ago
From the article:

> A 2024 GitHub survey found that nearly all enterprise developers (97%) are using Generative AI coding tools. These tools have rapidly evolved from experimental novelties to mission-critical development infrastructure, with teams across the globe relying on them daily to accelerate coding tasks.

That seemed high, what the actual report says:

> More than 97% of respondents reported having used AI coding tools at work at some point, a finding consistent across all four countries. However, a smaller percentage said their companies actively encourage AI tool adoption or allow the use of AI tools, varying by region. The U.S. leads with 88% of respondents indicating at least some company support for AI use, while Germany is lowest at 59%. This highlights an opportunity for organizations to better support their developers‚Äô interest in AI tools, considering local regulations.

Fun that the survey uses the stats to say that companies should support increasing usage, while the article uses it to try and show near-total usage already.
placardloop ‚Ä¢ 2 hours ago
I‚Äôd be pretty skeptical of any of these surveys about AI tool adoption. At my extremely large tech company, all developers were forced to install AI coding assistants into our IDEs and browsers (via managed software updates that can‚Äôt be uninstalled). Our company then put out press releases parading how great the AI adoption numbers were. The statistics are manufactured.
grumple ‚Ä¢ 5 minutes ago
This is surprising to me. My company (top 20 by revenue) has forbidden us from using non-approved AI tools (basically anything other than our own ChatGPT / LLM tool). Obviously it can't truly be enforced, but they do not want us using this stuff for security reasons.
bagacrap ‚Ä¢ 2 hours ago
-2 points
An AI powered autocompletion engine is an AI tool. I think few developers would complain about saving a few keystrokes.
sethops1 ‚Ä¢ 1 hour ago
I think few developers didn't already have powerful autocomplete engines at their disposal.
pdntspa ‚Ä¢ 52 minutes ago
The AI autocomplete I use (Jetbrains) stands head-and-shoulders above its non-AI autocomplete, and Jetbrains' autocomplete is already considered best-in-class. Its python support is so good that I still haven't figured out how to get anything even remotely close to it running in VSCode
_heimdall ‚Ä¢ 5 hours ago
> This highlights an opportunity for organizations to better support their developers‚Äô interest in AI tools, considering local regulations.

This is a funny one to see included in GitHub's report. If I'm not mistaken, github is now using the same approach as Shoplify with regards to requiring LLM use and including it as part of a self report survey for annual review.

I guess they took their 2024 survey to heart and are ready to 100x productivity.

NitpickLawyer ‚Ä¢ 9 hours ago
> the whole attack goes away once you fix that part.

While true, I think the main issue here, and the most impactful is that LLMs currently use a single channel for both "data" and "control". We've seen this before on modems (ath0++ attacks via ping packet payloads) and other tech stacks. Until we find a way to fix that, such attacks will always be possible, invisible text or not.
tsimionescu ‚Ä¢ 8 hours ago
I don't think that's an accurate way to look at how LLMs work, there is no possible separation between data and control given the fundamental nature of LLMs. LLMs are essentially a plain text execution engine. Their fundamental design is to take arbitrary human language as input, and produce output that matches that input in some way. I think the most accurate way to look at them from a traditional security model perspective is as a script engine that can execute arbitrary text data.

So, just like there is no realsitics hope of securely executing an attacker-controllers bash script, there is no realistic way to provide attacker controlled input to an LLM and still trust the output. In this sense, I completely agree with Google and Microsoft's decision for these discolosures: a bug report of the form "if I sneak a malicious prompt, the LLM returns a malicious answer" is as useless as a bug report in Bash that says that if you find a way to feed a malicious shell script to bash, it will execute it and produce malicious results.

So, the real problem is if people are not treating LLM control files as arbitrary scripts, or if tools don't help you detect attempts at inserting malicious content in said scripts. After all, I can also control your code base if you let me insert malicious instructions in your Makefile.

simonw ‚Ä¢ 4 hours ago
> I guess it's not a 100% effective, but it's something.

That's the problem: in the context of security, not being 100% effective is a failure.

If the ways we prevented XSS or SQL injection attacks against our apps only worked 99% of the time, those apps would all be hacked to pieces.

The job of an adversarial attacker is to find the 1% of attacks that work.

The instruction hierarchy is a great example: it doesn't solve the prompt injection class of attacks against LLM applications because it can still be subverted.
red75prime ‚Ä¢ 2 hours ago
Organizations face a similar problem: how to make reliable/secure processes out of fallible components (humans). The difference is that humans don't react in the same way to the same stimulus, so you can't hack all of them using the same trick, while computers react in a predictable way.

Maybe (in absence of long-term memory that would allow to patch such holes quickly) it would make sense to render LLMs less predictable in their reactions to adversarial stimuli by randomly perturbing initial state several times and comparing the results. Adversarial stimuli should be less robust to such perturbation as they are artifacts of insufficient training.
simonw ‚Ä¢ 2 hours ago
LLMs are already unpredictable in their responses which adds to the problem: you might test your system against a potential prompt injection three times and observe it resist the attack: an attacker might try another hundred times and have one of their attempts work.

namaria ‚Ä¢ 8 hours ago
> As mentioned by another comms ter, the solution could be to find a way to separate the command and data channels. The LLM only operates on a single channel, that being input of tokens.

I think the issue is deeper than that. None of the inputs to an LLM should be considered as command. It incidentally gives you output compatible with the language in what is phrased by people as commands. But the fact that it's all just data to the LLM and that it works by taking data and returning plausible continuations of that data is the root cause of the issue. The output is not determined by the input, it is only statistically linked. Anything built on the premise that it is possible to give commands to LLMs or to use it's output as commands is fundamentally flawed and bears security risks. No amount of 'guardrails' or 'mitigations' can address this fundamental fact.

Introducing GPT-4.1 in the API | OpenAI

April 14, 2025
Product
Introducing GPT-4.1 in the API

A new series of GPT models featuring major improvements on coding, instruction following, and long context‚Äîplus our first-ever nano model.
Try in Playground
Listen to article
18:14

Today, we‚Äôre launching three new models in the API: GPT‚Äë4.1, GPT‚Äë4.1 mini, and GPT‚Äë4.1 nano. These models outperform GPT‚Äë4o and GPT‚Äë4o mini across the board, with major gains in coding and instruction following. They also have larger context windows‚Äîsupporting up to 1 million tokens of context‚Äîand are able to better use that context with improved long-context comprehension. They feature a refreshed knowledge cutoff of June 2024.

GPT‚Äë4.1 excels at the following industry standard measures: 

    Coding: GPT‚Äë4.1 scores 54.6% on SWE-bench Verified, improving by 21.4%abs over GPT‚Äë4o and 26.6%abs over GPT‚Äë4.5‚Äîmaking it a leading model for coding.
    Instruction following: On Scale‚Äôs MultiChallenge‚Å†(opens in a new window) benchmark, a measure of instruction following ability, GPT‚Äë4.1 scores 38.3%, a 10.5%abs increase over GPT‚Äë4o.
    Long context: On Video-MME‚Å†(opens in a new window), a benchmark for multimodal long context understanding, GPT‚Äë4.1 sets a new state-of-the-art result‚Äîscoring 72.0% on the long, no subtitles category, a 6.7%abs improvement over GPT‚Äë4o.

While benchmarks provide valuable insights, we trained these models with a focus on real-world utility. Close collaboration and partnership with the developer community enabled us to optimize these models for the tasks that matter most to their applications.

To this end, the GPT‚Äë4.1 model family offers exceptional performance at a lower cost. These models push performance forward at every point on the latency curve.
GPT-4.1 family intelligence by latency

GPT‚Äë4.1 mini is a significant leap in small model performance, even beating GPT‚Äë4o in many benchmarks. It matches or exceeds GPT‚Äë4o in intelligence evals while reducing latency by nearly half and reducing cost by 83%. 

For tasks that demand low latency, GPT‚Äë4.1 nano is our fastest and cheapest model available. It delivers exceptional performance at a small size with its 1 million token context window, and scores 80.1% on MMLU, 50.3% on GPQA, and 9.8% on Aider polyglot coding‚Äîeven higher than GPT‚Äë4o mini. It‚Äôs ideal for tasks like classification or autocompletion.

These improvements in instruction following reliability and long context comprehension also make the GPT‚Äë4.1 models considerably more effective at powering agents, or systems that can independently accomplish tasks on behalf of users. When combined with primitives like the Responses API‚Å†(opens in a new window), developers can now build agents that are more useful and reliable at real-world software engineering, extracting insights from large documents, resolving customer requests with minimal hand-holding, and other complex tasks. 

Note that GPT‚Äë4.1 will only be available via the API. In ChatGPT, many of the improvements in instruction following, coding, and intelligence have been gradually incorporated into the latest version‚Å†(opens in a new window) of GPT‚Äë4o, and we will continue to incorporate more with future releases. 

We will also begin deprecating GPT‚Äë4.5 Preview in the API, as GPT‚Äë4.1 offers improved or similar performance on many key capabilities at much lower cost and latency. GPT‚Äë4.5 Preview will be turned off in three months, on July 14, 2025, to allow time for developers to transition. GPT‚Äë4.5 was introduced as a research preview to explore and experiment with a large, compute-intensive model, and we‚Äôve learned a lot from developer feedback. We‚Äôll continue to carry forward the creativity, writing quality, humor, and nuance you told us you appreciate in GPT‚Äë4.5 into future API models.

Below, we break down how GPT‚Äë4.1 performs across several benchmarks, along with examples from alpha testers like Windsurf, Qodo, Hex, Blue J, Thomson Reuters, and Carlyle that showcase how it performs in production on domain-specific tasks.
Coding

GPT‚Äë4.1 is significantly better than GPT‚Äë4o at a variety of coding tasks, including agentically solving coding tasks, frontend coding, making fewer extraneous edits, following diff formats reliably, ensuring consistent tool usage, and more.

On SWE-bench Verified, a measure of real-world software engineering skills, GPT‚Äë4.1 completes 54.6% of tasks, compared to 33.2% for GPT‚Äë4o (2024-11-20). This reflects improvements in model ability to explore a code repository, finish a task, and produce code that both runs and passes tests.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)OpenAI o3-mini (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4o mini55%33%41%49%38%24%9%SWE‚Äëbench Verified accuracy

For SWE-bench Verified, a model is given a code repository and issue description, and must generate a patch to solve the issue. Performance is highly dependent on the prompts and tools used. To aid in reproducing and contextualizing our results, we describe our setup for GPT‚Äë4.1 here‚Å†(opens in a new window). Our scores omit 23 of 500 problems whose solutions could not run on our infrastructure; if these are conservatively scored as 0, the 54.6% score becomes 52.1%.

For API developers looking to edit large files, GPT‚Äë4.1 is much more reliable at code diffs across a range of formats. GPT‚Äë4.1 more than doubles GPT‚Äë4o‚Äôs score on Aider‚Äôs polyglot diff benchmark‚Å†(opens in a new window), and even beats GPT‚Äë4.5 by 8%abs.This evaluation is both a measure of coding capabilities across various programming languages and a measure of model ability to produce changes in whole and diff formats. We‚Äôve specifically trained GPT‚Äë4.1 to follow diff formats more reliably, which allows developers to save both cost and latency by only having the model output changed lines, rather than rewriting an entire file. For best code diff performance, please refer to our prompting guide‚Å†(opens in a new window). For developers who prefer rewriting entire files, we‚Äôve increased output token limits for GPT‚Äë4.1 to 32,768 tokens (up from 16,384 tokens for GPT‚Äë4o). We also recommend using Predicted Outputs‚Å†(opens in a new window) to reduce latency of full file rewrites.

Aider‚Äôs polyglot benchmark accuracy

In Aider‚Äôs polyglot benchmark, models solve coding exercises from Exercism‚Å†(opens in a new window) by editing source files, with one retry allowed. The ‚Äòwhole‚Äô format requires the model to rewrite the entire file, which can be slow and costly. The ‚Äòdiff‚Äô format requires the model to write a series of search/replace blocks‚Å†(opens in a new window).

GPT‚Äë4.1 also substantially improves upon GPT‚Äë4o in frontend coding, and is capable of creating web apps that are more functional and aesthetically pleasing. In our head-to-head comparisons, paid human graders preferred GPT‚Äë4.1‚Äôs websites over GPT‚Äë4o‚Äôs 80% of the time.

Prompt: Make a flashcard web application. The user should be able to create flashcards, search through their existing flashcards, review flashcards, and see statistics on flashcards reviewed. Preload ten cards containing a Hindi word or phrase and its English translation. Review interface: In the review interface, clicking or pressing Space should flip the card with a smooth 3-D animation to reveal the translation. Pressing the arrow keys should navigate through cards. Search interface: The search bar should dynamically provide a list of results as the user types in a query. Statistics interface: The stats page should show a graph of the number of cards the user has reviewed, and the percentage they have gotten correct. Create cards interface: The create cards page should allow the user to specify the front and back of a flashcard and add to the user's collection. Each of these interfaces should be accessible in the sidebar. Generate a single page React app (put all styles inline).

GPT‚Äë4o

GPT‚Äë4.1

Beyond the benchmarks above, GPT‚Äë4.1 is better at following formats more reliably and makes extraneous edits less frequently. In our internal evals, extraneous edits on code dropped from 9% with GPT‚Äë4o to 2% with GPT‚Äë4.1.
Real world examples

Windsurf‚Å†(opens in a new window): GPT‚Äë4.1 scores 60% higher than GPT‚Äë4o on Windsurf‚Äôs internal coding benchmark, which correlates strongly with how often code changes are accepted on the first review. Their users noted that it was 30% more efficient in tool calling and about 50% less likely to repeat unnecessary edits or read code in overly narrow, incremental steps. These improvements translate into faster iteration and smoother workflows for engineering teams.

Qodo‚Å†(opens in a new window): Qodo tested GPT‚Äë4.1 head-to-head against other leading models on generating high-quality code reviews from GitHub pull requests using a methodology inspired by their fine-tuning benchmark. Across 200 meaningful real-world pull requests with the same prompts and conditions, they found that GPT‚Äë4.1 produced the better suggestion in 55% of cases‚Å†(opens in a new window). Notably, they found that GPT‚Äë4.1 excels at both precision (knowing when not to make suggestions) and comprehensiveness (providing thorough analysis when warranted), while maintaining focus on truly critical issues.
Instruction following

GPT‚Äë4.1 follows instructions more reliably, and we‚Äôve measured significant improvements across a variety of instruction following evals.

We developed an internal eval for instruction following to track model performance across a number of dimensions and in several key categories of instruction following, including:

    Format following. Providing instructions that specify a custom format for the model‚Äôs response, such as XML, YAML, Markdown, etc.
    Negative instructions. Specifying behavior the model should avoid. (Example: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask the user to contact support‚Äù)
    Ordered instructions. Providing a set of instructions the model must follow in a given order. (Example: ‚ÄúFirst ask for the user's name, then ask for their email‚Äù)
    Content requirements. Outputting content that includes certain information. (Example: ‚ÄúAlways include amount of protein when writing a nutrition plan‚Äù)
    Ranking. Ordering the output in a particular way. (Example: ‚ÄúSort the response by population count‚Äù)
    Overconfidence. Instructing the model to say ‚ÄúI don't know‚Äù or similar if requested information isn't available, or the request doesn‚Äôt fall in a given category. (Example: ‚ÄúIf you do not know the answer, provide the support contact email‚Äù)

These categories are the result of feedback from developers regarding which facets of instruction following are most relevant and important to them. Within each category, we‚Äôve split up easy, medium, and hard prompts. GPT‚Äë4.1 improves significantly over GPT‚Äë4o on hard prompts in particular.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)OpenAI o3-mini (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini49%29%51%50%54%45%32%27%Internal OpenAI Instructions following eval accuracy (hard subset)

Our internal instruction following eval is based on real developer use cases and feedback, covering tasks of varying complexity coupled with instructions on formatting, verbosity, length, and more.

Multi-turn instruction following is critical for many developers‚Äîit‚Äôs important for the model to maintain coherence deep into a conversation, and keep track of what the user told it earlier. We‚Äôve trained GPT‚Äë4.1 to be better able to pick out information from past messages in the conversation, allowing for more natural conversations. The MultiChallenge benchmark from Scale is a useful measure of this capability, and GPT‚Äë4.1 performs 10.5%abs better than GPT‚Äë4o.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)OpenAI o3-mini (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini38%28%45%40%44%36%15%20%MultiChallenge accuracy

In MultiChallenge‚Å†(opens in a new window), models are challenged on multi-turn conversations to properly use four types of information from previous messages.

GPT‚Äë4.1 also scores 87.4% on IFEval, compared to 81.0% for GPT‚Äë4o. IFEval uses prompts with verifiable instructions (for example, specifying content length or avoiding certain terms or formats).
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)OpenAI o3-mini (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini87%81%92%94%88%84%75%78%IFEval accuracy

In IFEval‚Å†(opens in a new window), models must generate answers that comply with various instructions.

Better instruction following makes existing applications more reliable, and enables new applications previously limited by poor reliability. Early testers noted that GPT‚Äë4.1 can be more literal, so we recommend being explicit and specific in prompts. For more on prompting best practices for GPT‚Äë4.1, please refer to the prompting guide.
Real world examples

Blue J‚Å†(opens in a new window): GPT‚Äë4.1 was 53% more accurate than GPT‚Äë4o on an internal benchmark of Blue J‚Äôs most challenging real-world tax scenarios. This jump in accuracy‚Äîkey to both system performance and user satisfaction‚Äîhighlights GPT‚Äë4.1‚Äôs improved comprehension of complex regulations and its ability to follow nuanced instructions over long contexts. For Blue J users, that means faster, more reliable tax research and more time for high-value advisory work.

Hex‚Å†(opens in a new window): GPT‚Äë4.1 delivered a nearly 2√ó improvement on Hex‚Äôs most challenging SQL evaluation set,‚Å†(opens in a new window) showcasing significant gains in instruction following and semantic understanding. The model was more reliable in selecting the correct tables from large, ambiguous schemas‚Äîan upstream decision point that directly impacts overall accuracy and is difficult to tune through prompting alone. For Hex, this resulted in a measurable reduction in manual debugging and a faster path to production-grade workflows.
Long Context

GPT‚Äë4.1, GPT‚Äë4.1 mini, and GPT‚Äë4.1 nano can process up to 1 million tokens of context‚Äîup from 128,000 for previous GPT‚Äë4o models. 1 million tokens is more than 8 copies of the entire React codebase, so long context is a great fit for processing large codebases, or lots of long documents.

We trained GPT‚Äë4.1 to reliably attend to information across the full 1 million context length. We‚Äôve also trained it to be far more reliable than GPT‚Äë4o at noticing relevant text, and ignoring distractors across long and short context lengths. Long-context understanding is a critical capability for applications across legal, coding, customer support, and many other domains.

Below, we demonstrate GPT‚Äë4.1‚Äôs ability to retrieve a small hidden piece of information (a ‚Äúneedle‚Äù) positioned at various points within the context window. GPT‚Äë4.1 consistently retrieves the needle accurately at all positions and all context lengths, all the way up to 1 million tokens. It is effectively able to pull out relevant details for the task at hand regardless of their position in the input.
GPT-4.1 Needle in a Haystack accuracy graph

In our internal needle in a haystack eval, GPT‚Äë4.1, GPT‚Äë4.1 mini, and GPT 4.1 nano are all able to retrieve the needle at all positions in the context up to 1M.

However, few real-world tasks are as straightforward as retrieving a single, obvious needle answer. We find users often need our models to retrieve and understand multiple pieces of information, and to understand those pieces in relation to each other. To showcase this capability, we‚Äôre open-sourcing a new eval: OpenAI-MRCR (Multi-Round Coreference). 

OpenAI-MRCR tests the model‚Äôs ability to find and disambiguate between multiple needles well hidden in context. The evaluation consists of multi-turn synthetic conversations between a user and assistant where the user asks for a piece of writing about a topic, for example "write a poem about tapirs" or "write a blog post about rocks". We then insert two, four, or eight identical requests throughout the context. The model must then retrieve the response corresponding to a specific instance (e.g., ‚Äúgive me the third poem about tapirs‚Äù).

The challenge arises from the similarity between these requests and the rest of the context‚Äîmodels can easily be misled by subtle differences, such as a short story about tapirs rather than a poem, or a poem about frogs instead of tapirs. We find that GPT‚Äë4.1 outperforms GPT‚Äë4o at context lengths up to 128K tokens and maintains strong performance even up to 1 million tokens.

But the task remains hard‚Äîeven for advanced reasoning models. We‚Äôre sharing the eval dataset‚Å†(opens in a new window) to encourage further work on real-world long-context retrieval.
OpenAI MRCR accuracy, 2 needle

In OpenAI-MRCR‚Å†(opens in a new window), the model must answer a question that involves disambiguating between 2, 4, or 8 user prompts scattered amongst distractors.
OpenAI MRCR accuracy, 4 needle

In OpenAI-MRCR‚Å†(opens in a new window), the model must answer a question that involves disambiguating between 2, 4, or 8 user prompts scattered amongst distractors.
OpenAI MRCR accuracy, 8 needle

In OpenAI-MRCR‚Å†(opens in a new window), the model must answer a question that involves disambiguating between 2, 4, or 8 user prompts scattered amongst distractors.

We‚Äôre also releasing Graphwalks‚Å†(opens in a new window), a dataset for evaluating multi-hop long-context reasoning. Many developer use cases for long context require multiple logical hops within the context, like jumping between multiple files when writing code or cross referencing documents when answering complicated legal questions.

A model (or even a human) could theoretically solve an OpenAI-MRCR problem by doing one pass or read-through of the prompt, but Graphwalks is designed to require reasoning across multiple positions in the context and cannot be solved sequentially.

Graphwalks fills the context window with a directed graph composed of hexadecimal hashes, and then asks the model to perform a breadth-first search (BFS) starting from a random node in the graph. We then ask it to return all nodes at a certain depth. GPT‚Äë4.1 achieves 61.7% accuracy on this benchmark, matching the performance of o1 and beating GPT‚Äë4o handily.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)OpenAI o3-mini (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini62%42%62%51%72%62%25%29%Graphwalks BFS <128k accuracy

In Graphwalks‚Å†(opens in a new window), a model is asked to perform a breadth-first search from a random node in a large graph.

Benchmarks don‚Äôt tell the full story, so we worked with alpha partners to test the performance of GPT‚Äë4.1 on their real-world long context tasks.
Real world examples

Thomson Reuters:‚Å†(opens in a new window) Thomson Reuters tested GPT‚Äë4.1 with CoCounsel, their professional grade AI assistant for legal work. Compared to GPT‚Äë4o, they were able to improve multi-document review accuracy by 17% when using GPT‚Äë4.1 across internal long-context benchmarks‚Äîan essential measure of CoCounsel‚Äôs ability to handle complex legal workflows involving multiple, lengthy documents. In particular, they found the model to be highly reliable at maintaining context across sources and accurately identifying nuanced relationships between documents, such as conflicting clauses or additional supplementary context‚Äîtasks critical to legal analysis and decision-making.

Carlyle‚Å†(opens in a new window): Carlyle used GPT‚Äë4.1 to accurately extract granular financial data across multiple, lengthy documents‚Äîincluding PDFs, Excel files, and other complex formats. Based on their internal evaluations, it performed 50% better on retrieval from very large documents with dense data and was the first model to successfully overcome key limitations seen with other available models, including needle-in-the-haystack retrieval, lost-in-the-middle errors, and multi-hop reasoning across documents.

In addition to model performance and accuracy, developers also need models that respond quickly to keep up with and meet users‚Äô needs. We've improved our inference stack to reduce the time to first token, and with prompt caching, you can cut latency even further while saving on costs. In our initial testing, latency to first token for GPT‚Äë4.1 was approximately fifteen seconds with 128,000 tokens of context, and a minute for a million tokens of context. GPT‚Äë4.1 mini and nano are faster, e.g., GPT‚Äë4.1 nano most often returns the first token in less than five seconds for queries with 128,000 input tokens.
Vision

The GPT‚Äë4.1 family is exceptionally strong at image understanding, with GPT‚Äë4.1 mini in particular representing a significant leap forward, often beating GPT‚Äë4o on image benchmarks.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini75%69%78%75%73%55%56%MMMU accuracy

In MMMU‚Å†(opens in a new window), a model answers questions containing charts, diagrams, maps, etc. (Note: even when the image is not included, many answers can still be inferred or guessed from context.)
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini72%61%72%72%73%56%57%MathVista accuracy

In MathVista‚Å†(opens in a new window), a model solves visual mathematical tasks.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)OpenAI o1 (high)GPT-4.5GPT-4.1 miniGPT-4.1 nanoGPT-4o mini57%53%55%55%57%41%37%CharXiv-Reasoning accuracy

In CharXiv-Reasoning‚Å†(opens in a new window), a model answers questions about charts from scientific papers.

Long context performance is also important for multimodal use cases, such as processing long videos. In Video-MME‚Å†(opens in a new window) (long w/o subs), a model answers multiple choice questions based on 30-60 minute long videos with no subtitles. GPT‚Äë4.1 achieves state-of-the-art performance, scoring 72.0%, up from 65.3% for GPT‚Äë4o.
GPT-4.1GPT-4o (2024-11-20)72%65%Video long context

In Video-MME‚Å†(opens in a new window), a model answers multiple choice questions based on 30-60 minute long videos with no subtitles.
Pricing

GPT‚Äë4.1, GPT‚Äë4.1 mini, and GPT‚Äë4.1 nano are available now to all developers. 

Through efficiency improvements to our inference systems, we‚Äôve been able to offer lower prices on the GPT‚Äë4.1 series.GPT‚Äë4.1 is 26% less expensive than GPT‚Äë4o for median queries, and GPT‚Äë4.1 nano is our cheapest and fastest model ever. For queries that repeatedly pass the same context, we are increasing the prompt caching discount to 75% (up from 50% previously) for these new models. Finally, we offer long context requests at no additional cost beyond the standard per-token costs.

These models are available for use in our Batch API‚Å†(opens in a new window) at an additional 50% pricing discount.
Conclusion

GPT‚Äë4.1 is a significant step forward in the practical application of AI. By focusing closely on real-world developer needs‚Äîranging from coding to instruction-following and long context understanding‚Äîthese models unlock new possibilities for building intelligent systems and sophisticated agentic applications. We‚Äôre continually inspired by the developer community‚Äôs creativity, and are excited to see what you build with GPT‚Äë4.1.
Appendix

A full list of results across academic, coding, instruction following, long context, vision, and function calling evals can be found below.

I‚Äôve downloaded a new version of Inter from the website itself. For some reason, the one that appears in Figma is the old version from Google Fonts. I want to use the new version of Inter because the italics are better than the Google Fonts‚Äô version.

Here‚Äôs the comparison between the two (bottom is old, top is new):
Screenshot displaying the text ‚ÄúLost one‚Äôs weeping‚Äù in two different versions of Inter font. The top is the new version, while the bottom is the old version

I tried following the guide for managing conflicting fonts, but it yields the same results. Is there a workaround for this?

Best answer by Celine_D

Hey @Ethan_M ,
This looks odd! Which steps have you already tried?

As explained in the Help Center article:
Inter is Figma‚Äôs interface font and is one of the default fonts we provide in Figma. If you also have Inter installed on your device, Figma will use this version over the one provided by Figma. If your organization uploads Inter as a shared font, Figma will use this version in files.

I tried to install directly with your link the new version of Inter and install in my device by following their instructions:
ON MAC

    Open the ‚ÄúFont Book‚Äù application.
    In the main menu, select ‚ÄúFile‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúAdd Fonts‚Ä¶‚Äù
    Select ‚ÄúInter.ttc‚Äù, ‚ÄúInterVariable.ttf‚Äù and ‚ÄúInterVariable-Italic.ttf‚Äù
    Press the ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù button

ON WINDOWS
Open the zip file you downloaded
Select ‚ÄúInter.ttc‚Äù, ‚ÄúInterVariable.ttf‚Äù and ‚ÄúInterVariable-Italic.ttf‚Äù
Right-click the selected files, choose ‚ÄúInstall for all users‚Äù
If you have a previous installation of Inter, you should make sure to remove those fonts files before installing new ones. You need to install the font for all users, as some software requires fonts to be global.

Then, the new version of Inter appears on my Figma:
Screenshot 2024-02-20 at 10.37.27

Can you please try to uninstall and reinstall the new version of Inter by following these steps, then refresh your tab to see if that helps? Let us know if it works on your end!

Open the zip file you downloaded
Select ‚ÄúInter.ttc‚Äù, ‚ÄúInterVariable.ttf‚Äù and ‚ÄúInterVariable-Italic.ttf‚Äù
Right-click the selected files, choose ‚ÄúInstall for all users‚Äù
If you have a previous installation of Inter, you should make sure to remove those fonts files before installing new ones. You need to install the font for all users, as some software requires fonts to be global.

Then, the new version of Inter appears on my Figma:
Screenshot 2024-02-20 at 10.37.27

Can you please try to uninstall and reinstall the new version of Inter by following these steps, then refresh your tab to see if that helps? Let us know if it works on your end!

results.title: Daily Calendar for Sunday, April 6, 2025 | Almanac.com
results.content:
Question of the Day 
 Where did the phrase ‚Äúmad as a hatter‚Äù come from? Why was the ‚Äúhatter‚Äù considered mad? Madness was not a prerequisite for the milliner‚Äôs craft, but, unfortunately, in the 19th century mercurous nitrate was used in the making of felt hats, and it produced tremors akin to St. Vitus‚Äô dance; this is the likely origin of the saying. (Lewis Carroll popularized the phrase in his book, Alice in Wonderland.) 
 Advice of the Day 
 
 Happiness is a by-product. You can not pursue it by itself. ‚ÄîSamuel Levenson 
 
 Home Hint of the Day 
 
 When clearing smaller brush, consider pulling the brush out of the ground instead of cutting it down. If you get the roots, the brush won‚Äôt come up again. 
 
 Word of the Day 
 Solar eclipse Earth enters the shadow of the new Moon, which cuts off all or part of the Sun‚Äôs light. Total: Earth passes through the umbra (central dark part) of the Moon‚Äôs shadow, resulting in totality for observers within a narrow band on Earth. Annular: The Moon appears silhouetted against the Sun, with a ring of sunlight showing around it. Partial: The Moon blocks only part of the Sun. 
 Puzzle of the Day 
 What do you get from a pampered cow? 
 
 
 Died

) ‚Äì 1998

 Twin mongoose lemurs (born at Busch Gardens, Tampa, Florida) ‚Äì 2012 
 
 
 
 
 
 Events 
 
 Brigham Young, the Mormon Church leader, married his 27th and last wife ‚Äì 1868 
 
 Snow-melting apparatus patented ‚Äì 1869 
 
 Vancouver, British Columbia, was incorporated ‚Äì 1886 
 
 The first modern Olympic Games opened in Athens, Greece ‚Äì 1896 
 
 Admiral Robert Peary and his African-American assistant Matthew Henson reached what was believed to be the North Pole ‚Äì 1909 
 
 The U.S. declared war on Germany (WW I) ‚Äì 1917 
 
 Bakery manager, Jimmy Dewar, invented a cream filled sponge cake, now known as the Twinkie ‚Äì 1930 
 
 The first Tony Awards were presented at a dinner in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf Astoria hotel on Easter Sunday ‚Äì 1947 
 
 Paramount Pictures signed Elvis Presley to a three-movie contract just five days after his first screen test ‚Äì 1956 
 
 Intelsat-1 (nicknamed Early Bird), the world‚Äôs first commercial geosynchronous communications satellite, was launched from Cape Kennedy (now Cape Canaveral) in Florida ‚Äì 1965 
 
 Microsoft released Windows 3.1 ‚Äì 1992 
 
 UConn‚Äôs women‚Äôs basketball team completed a championship sweep for the school by beating Tennessee 70-61 for the NCAA women‚Äôs title. The victory followed UConn‚Äôs win over Georgia Tech in the men‚Äôs championship game the previous night, making Connecticut the first Division I school to sweep both titles ‚Äì 2004 
 
 A magnitude-6.3 earthquake struck central Italy ‚Äì 2009

results.title: National Holidays on April 6th, 2025 | Days Of The Year
results.content:
National Tartan Day 
 
 Research the history and culture of the Scottish people, represented by the iconic Tartan pattern often seen on kilts, blankets, and other clothing. 
 
 
 
 Hostess Twinkie Day 
 
 Savoring the timeless delight of golden sponge cakes with a luscious, creamy filling ‚Äî an iconic treat that endures. 
 
 
 
 National Pajama Day 
 
 Embracing comfort all day, an effortless shift from formal wear to cozy pajamas adds a delightful twist to routines. 
 
 
 See what else is going on Apr 6th 
 
 Rise and shine, you adventurous soul! Start your day by donning your favorite tartan pajamas ‚Äì we‚Äôre diving headfirst into a day packed with excitement. After a cozy breakfast in your comfiest PJs, it‚Äôs time to jump over some everyday objects around your house. Why not get creative and set up a mini obstacle course with pillows and chairs? 
As the midday hunger pangs hit, whip up a delicious carbonara or have a burrito fiesta to celebrate National Carbonara Day and National Burrito Day . If you‚Äôre feeling extra indulgent, munch on some caramel popcorn while basking in the joy of being a student athlete ‚Äì after all, it‚Äôs National Student Athlete Day . 
Feeling a bit mischievous? Celebrate Tell a Lie Day by playing a harmless prank on a friend or family member. Embrace the spirit of New Beer‚Äôs Eve and enjoy a cold one as you plan your epitaph ‚Äì a quirky activity to get your creative juices flowing. 
In the evening, cuddle up with your beloved Siamese cat and watch a sports documentary to honor International Day of Sport for Development and Peace . Cap off the day by treating yourself to a Twinkie dessert while pondering the importance of fun in the workplace on International Fun at Work Day . 
Remember, life is too short to be serious all the time. So, embrace the weird, wacky, and wonderful holidays that make each day a little bit more exciting and offbeat. Now go forth and make the most of this unexpectedly delightful mishmash of celebrations! 
 
 
 International Asexuality Day 
 
 Exploring the spectrum of human sexuality, acknowledging diverse identities and promoting understanding and inclusivity for all individuals. 
 
 
 
 Tangible Karma Day 
 
 De-clutter your life and help the planet at the same time, by passing on your less-used items to another. On Tangible Karma Day, it might just come back around. 
 
 
 
 National Student Athlete Day 
 
 Balancing books and sports, they embody dedication, resilience‚Äîchampions navigating both the academic arena and athletic fields seamlessly. 
 
 
 
 National Carbonara Day 
 
 Rich pasta, melding salty pancetta, creamy egg, and Parmesan‚Äîa flavor dance that captivates discerning palates effortlessly. 
 
 
 
 National Acai Bowl Day 
 
 A bowl of tropical paradise in every bite! Rich in antioxidants and vitamins, this sweet and refreshing treat is perfect anytime. 
 
 
 
 National Siamese Cat Day 
 
 Intelligent, playful and loyal, their distinct looks and vocal personalities make them an instantly recognizable and beloved cat breed. 
 
 
 
 National Handmade Day 
 
 Supporting local artisans, who craft unique items with care and love, is a great way to appreciate their creativity. 
 
 
 
 National DIY Day 
 
 Learn a new skill and enjoy the self-satisfaction of ‚Äúdoing it yourself‚Äù on National DIY Day. Try knitting a scarf, building a chair, or cooking something new. 
 
 
 
 New Beer‚Äôs Eve 
 
 Crack open a cold one with friends or family, and toast to the end of Prohibition and the return of yeasty, hoppy, refreshing and delicious beer on New Beer‚Äôs Day. 
 
 
 
 National Caramel Popcorn Day 
 
 Sweet and salty, crunchy and soft: opposites attract on National Caramel Popcorn Day, so forget your diet and enjoy one of the nation‚Äôs tastiest snacks. 
 
 
 
 Army Day 
 
 Thank a veteran, donate to the cause, or volunteer to help the nation‚Äôs frontline, who often suffer PTSD, poverty, and loss for their sacrifices to their country. 
 
 
 
 International Pillow Fight Day 
 
 Let loose and connect with others by joining or organizing a pillow fight. Join your family, roommates, or even your whole community to let the feathers fly. 
 
 
 
 Plan Your Epitaph Day 
 
 Take some time to think about and plan how you want to be remembered forever: Plan Your Epitaph day is to choose what you want engraved on your tombstone. 
 
 
 
 International Firewalk Day 
 
 Firewalking is an ancient practice that relies on skill and confidence to literally walk through fire without getting burned. Learn from an expert‚Äînot at home! 
 
 
 Mon Apr 1st, 2024 - Sun Apr 7th, 2024 
 
 
 National Wildlife Week 
 
 Nature's tapestry, harmonious ecosystems, where diverse creatures coexist, weaving a story of survival and interconnected existence. 
 
 
 
 Mon Apr 1st, 2024 - Tue Apr 23rd, 2024 
 
 
 FOP Awareness Month 
 
 Raising awareness for a rare condition, efforts unite to support those facing the challenges of Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva. 
 
 
 
 Sun Mar 10th, 2024 - Mon Apr 8th, 2024 
 
 
 Ramadan 
 
 During this holy month, Muslims fast from sunrise to sunset, focusing on spiritual reflection and community. Ramadan is a time for self-improvement and bringing people together in celebration of faith. 
 
 
 
 Tue Mar 19th, 2024 - Mon Apr 8th, 2024 
 
 
 March Madness 
 
 Get your game face on for March Madness! This high-energy tournament is a slam dunk of excitement, passion, and heart-pumping action. So grab your team colors, gear up for the showdown, and let the madness begin! 
 
 
 
 Mon Apr 1st, 2024 - Sun Apr 7th, 2024 
 
 
 National Public Health Week 
 
 The well-being of communities ‚Äî disease prevention, and better living through knowledge and action, towards a healthier world. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 International Guitar Month 
 
 Exploring melodies, strings resonate with rhythm, evoking emotions and stories through the power of music. 
 
 
 
 Global Volunteer Month 
 
 Supporting causes, aiding communities, and making a difference, volunteering enriches lives and fosters connections among people. 
 
 
 
 National Alcohol Awareness Month 
 
 Promoting mindful choices, understanding limits, fostering informed decisions for a healthier relationship with alcohol and well-being. 
 
 
 
 National Soy Foods Month 
 
 Exploring a diverse palate with plant-based delicacies, discovering the savory richness and versatility of nourishing soy creations. 
 
 
 
 National Food Month 
 
 Savor diverse culinary delights, a journey of tastes transcending borders, igniting a symphony on your palate. 
 
 
 
 National Month of Hope 
 
 Persistent light, enduring strength, unwavering spirit, an anchor in uncertainty, a beacon through challenges, resilient optimism. 
 
 
 
 National Soft Pretzel Month 
 
 Twisted dough, golden brown, salty delight, satisfying cravings ‚Äî the perfect snack for any occasion, simply delicious. 
 
 
 
 National Volunteer Month 
 
 Contributing time and effort, making a positive impact, these endeavors embody the spirit of selflessness and community betterment. 
 
 
 
 Sexual Assault Awareness Month 
 
 Realities exposed, voices united‚Äîconfronting challenges and fostering empathy in the quest for justice and healing after assault. 
 
 
 
 National Kite Month 
 
 Whispers of wind, colorful fabrics dancing, defying gravity ‚Äî an artful ballet where tethered dreams ascend the sky's canvas. 
 
 
 
 National Garden Month 
 
 Spring is in the air! Explore the beauty of gardens, or get some dirt under your own nails, whether from pots by the window or a flowery expanse of your own. 
 
 
 
 National Poetry Month 
 
 Lord Byron, Shel Silverstein, Emily Dickinson‚Ä¶you? Honor one of the richest literary forms by writing or reading poetry, learning about poets, or joining a community. 
 
 
 
 Autism Acceptance Month 
 
 Support research and education, learn about the symptoms and effects, and be better prepared to help those with autism in your life during Autism Acceptance Month. 
 
 
 
 National Pickleball Month 
 
 Amidst spirited rallies, a sport emerges, blending finesse and camaraderie, captivating enthusiasts with its distinctive charm on the court. 
 
 
 
 Stress Awareness Month 
 
 Stress is linked to physical, mental, and emotional health. During Stress Awareness Month, learn about what triggers stress and how to manage it. 
 
 
 
 National Jazz Appreciation Month 
 
 Learn about the history and heritage of jazz, listen to the greats, or find a local jazz club to engage with one of the United States‚Äô richest musical movements. 
 
 
 
 Poetic Earth Month 
 
 Allow the Earth‚Äôs beauty to inspire you, and enjoy and share poetry, stories, or art to connect with your planet during Poetic Earth Month. 
 
 
 
 National Couple Appreciation Month 
 
 Take some time to appreciate romance and companionship, whether with a romantic getaway or date, or a just a small gesture reminding your person how you feel. 
 
 
 
 Adopt A Ferret Month 
 
 Is it a cat? Is it a snake? Yes, it‚Äôs a ferret! These uncommon but loveable pets can make a great addition to the right home, but make sure to do your research first. 
 
 
 
 Straw Hat Month 
 
 They block the sun, keep the rain off, evoke a simpler time and place, and look timelessly stylish. If you don‚Äôt have a straw hat yet, it might be time to get one. 
 
 
 
 Month of the Military Child 
 
 Wear purple to honor the sacrifices and stress involved in being a military kid: separation, losing or fearing the loss of a parent, frequent moving, and more. 
 
 
 
 Active Dog Month 
 
 Dogs need exercise and fun just as much‚Äîif not more‚Äîthan their humans. Bond with your furry friends by playing, running, or exploring new places with them. 
 
 
 
 Summer Tire Changeover Month 
 
 Different treads and tire designs are better for different conditions. So as the weather warms up, don‚Äôt forget to change from your Winter tires to your Summer tires. 
 
 
 
 National Decorating Month 
 
 Get creative and crafty, and bring life back to your home by painting, arranging furniture, and otherwise decorating the space you spend so much time in. 
 
 
 
 Parkinson‚Äôs Awareness Month 
 
 Learn about the effects of Parkinson‚Äôs Disease, how to help those who have it, or donate to foundations and research during Parkinson‚Äôs Awareness Month. 
 
 
 See everything in April 2024

To best assist you, could you clarify what kind of notes you're referring to (e.g., are they in a specific application like Evernote, OneNote, a web-based note service, or something else)?

Okay, I understand. You're using Anytype and images you pasted into your notes from the clipboard are now broken on both your computer and laptop. You're not sure if the image files themselves were deleted or just the links.

Here's a breakdown of what might be happening and how to troubleshoot:

**Understanding the Issue**

*   **How Anytype Handles Images:** Anytype is an offline-first application, meaning your data is stored locally first and then synced. When you paste an image from your clipboard, Anytype *should* be saving a copy of that image within its storage. It's *not* just a simple link to an external file.
*   **Possible Causes:**
    1.  **Data Corruption/Sync Issues:** It's possible there was an issue during the syncing process between your devices, or a problem with the local data storage on one or both devices.
    2.  **Accidental Deletion (Less Likely):** While less likely *if* you didn't intentionally delete anything, it's *possible* the images were inadvertently removed from Anytype's storage.
    3.  **Bug in Anytype:** It's also possible that this is a bug within the Anytype software itself, particularly related to image handling or caching.
    4.  **Link issues:** It's possible that there are issues with the way Anytype is linking to the files, but the files have not been deleted.

**Troubleshooting Steps**

1.  **Check the Anytype Bin:**
    *   Within Anytype, look for a "Bin" or "Trash" area. See if the missing images are located there. If so, you can restore them.
2.  **Check Anytype's File Management:**
    *   Anytype has a file management section. Look for options like "Manage Space" or "Manage Files" within Anytype's settings. This *might* give you a view of the images Anytype has stored.
3.  **Clear Cache (Mobile Devices):**
    *   If you're also using Anytype on a mobile device (Android or iOS), try clearing the app's cache. This can sometimes resolve issues with media files.
4.  **Syncing:**
    *   Make sure Anytype has fully synced across all of your devices. Look for a sync status indicator within the app.
5.  **Check the Anytype Community and Bug Reports:**
    *   The Anytype Community forum is a good place to see if others are experiencing similar issues. Check the "Bug Reports" section specifically.
6.  **Contact Anytype Support:**
    *   If none of the above steps work, your best bet is to contact Anytype support directly.

**How to Report the Issue to Anytype (If Necessary)**

*   **Be Clear and Specific:** When contacting support, provide the following information:
    *   The version of Anytype you are using on each device.
    *   The steps you took that led to the problem (pasting images from the clipboard).
    *   When the issue started occurring.
    *   Whether you've tried any troubleshooting steps already.
*   **Include Screenshots:** If possible, include screenshots of the broken images in your notes.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
